channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Backs Away From Demand for Immediate North Korean Denuclearization
item.description: The president’s hint of flexibility came after North Korea declared last week that it would never agree to unilaterally surrender its weapons and threatened to cancel a June summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Can Trump Still Claim Victory if Kim Jong-un Keeps His Nuclear Arms?
item.media:description: With North Korean denuclearization apparently off the table — at least in the short term — the question is how President Trump will redefine success, if his talks with the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, take place next month as planned.
item.description: North Korean denuclearization is off the table, at least in the short term. But there are other outcomes from the planned summit talks that President Trump might accept.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Is Facebook Just a Platform? A Lawyer to the Stars Says No
item.media:description: “I say to Facebook, ‘What is the difference between you and a national newspaper being responsible for the letters they publish on their letters page? Why do you have to be treated differently?” said the lawyer Paul Tweed.
item.media:credit: Brian Lawless/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Paul Tweed attracted star clients by suing publishers in Belfast, London and Dublin. He plans to hold the social media giants to the same standards.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: London Journal: The Red Phone Box, a British Icon, Stages a Comeback
item.media:description: A rusting graveyard or a forest of opportunity? Many of the emblematic kiosks are being rescued from the scrap heap.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Once unwanted relics, the booths are being retooled in imaginative ways, including as cellphone repair shops, tiny cafes and defibrillator sites.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Palestinians Ask Hague Court to Open Full Inquiry Into Israel
item.media:description: At least 60 Palestinians were killed by Israeli fire during protests last week at the Gaza border. Palestinian officials have asked the International Criminal Court to investigate.
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.description: Israel immediately challenged the request, which came a week after at least 60 Palestinians were killed by Israeli fire in protests at the Gaza border.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS and ALAN COWELL
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Denmark Minister Calls Fasting Muslims ‘a Danger’ in Ramadan
item.media:description: Inger Stojberg, Denmark’s immigration minister, during a 2016 debate on a contentious bill that included allowing the police to seize migrants’ valuables.
item.description: The minister, Inger Stojberg, said fasting Muslims should stay home from work “to avoid negative consequences for the rest of Danish society.”
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN

item.title: On Manchester Attack Anniversary, Songs and Silence for Resilient City
item.media:description: Observing the anniversary of a terrorist bombing on Tuesday in Manchester, England.
item.description: The English city held a day of commemorations including a memorial service to honor the 22 who died, a moment of silence and an event bringing together more than 80 choirs.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Turkey Hands Life Sentences to 104 People Over Coup Attempt
item.media:description: Clothes and weapons belonging to soldiers who surrendered after the coup attempt in Istanbul in July 2016.
item.description: Two crucial witnesses turned against fellow defendants and revealed details of the failed effort to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in 2016.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Nicolás Maduro Expels Top U.S. Diplomats from Venezuela
item.media:description: Todd D. Robinson, right, the chargé d’affaires of the United States Embassy in Venezuela, in Caracas last week.
item.description: The newly re-elected president accused the American envoys of conspiring against his government and gave them 48 hours to leave.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: White House, Facebook, Georgia: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Street Style: Copenhagen
item.description: In Denmark’s capital, bicycles are the most common accessory.

item.title: Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg Gets an Earful From the E.U.
item.media:description: The Facebook chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, went to the European Parliament in Brussels on Tuesday to answer lawmakers’ questions over his social media company’s handling of user data.
item.description: The chief executive had initially resisted meeting with European authorities, who have emerged as the world’s most assertive watchdog of the technology industry.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO and MILAN SCHREUER

item.title: 16 Dead in Afghanistan After Car Bomb Explodes as Team Tries to Defuse It
item.media:description: Afghan intelligence agents tracked a Taliban car bomb to a garage in Kandahar on Tuesday, but they failed to disarm it. Most of those killed by the explosion were civilians, officials said.
item.description: Intelligence agents tracked a Taliban car bomb to an auto repair garage in Kandahar, but they failed in their attempt to disarm it.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Anniversary of Thai Coup Draws Uneasy Protest and Police Threats
item.media:description: Pro-democracy activists scuffled with the police before being detained in Bangkok on Tuesday, the fourth anniversary of a coup that returned the country to military rule.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Officials in Bangkok warned that demonstrators fighting for a return to civilian government had been identified through photographs and video footage, and that they could be prosecuted.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)

item.title: Is This the World’s Most Diverse National Park?
item.media:description: Rice rat
item.description: Bringing the numbers to life for the jewel in Bolivia’s conservation crown.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN

item.title: China Cuts Car Tariffs, in a Small Offering to the U.S. on Trade
item.media:description: China’s tariffs for imported cars will still be relatively high, and the change is unlikely to motivate automakers to shift production.
item.description: The moves are likely to change little for the auto industry, though Chinese factories and German firms could benefit from slashing tariffs on parts.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: With Senator’s Snub, Australia Gets Stood Up by U.S. — Again
item.media:description: Senator Bob Corker was picked by President Trump to serve as America’s ambassador to Australia. On Tuesday, he turned down the job.
item.media:credit: Lawrence Jackson for The New York Times
item.description: Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee declined to become the ambassador, just weeks after President Trump’s previous choice was reassigned. Should Australia be taking this personally?
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Want to See Your Baby? In China, It Can Cost You
item.media:description: Huadu District People’s Hospital in Guangzhou, China, where Juliana Brandy Logbo, a Liberian, gave birth to twins this month but wasn’t allowed to see them, she said, until she had raised hundreds of dollars to pay medical fees.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: A hospital demanded that a woman pay her bills before she could see her newborn twins, illustrating a plight that many face in the Chinese medical system.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Trump-Kim Meeting Is Yet to Come, but U.S. Has Minted the Coins
item.media:description: The coin issued by the White House Communications Agency, a military unit that handles presidential communications.
item.description: The White House was criticized over commemorative coins to honor the planned meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Macron Vowed to Make France a ‘Start-Up Nation.’ Is It Getting There?
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, the French president, at the opening of the technology incubator Station F in Paris last June. He has vowed to make France a “start-up nation.”
item.description: France has quickly become one of the hottest destinations in Europe for technology investment, but it faces big challenges in its mission to become a leader.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: In Australia, Fears of Chinese Meddling Rise on U.N. Bribery Case Revelation
item.media:description: Chau Chak Wing, center right, in 2015 at the opening of a University of Technology Sydney building that bears his name. Dr. Chau is accused of bribing a United Nations diplomat.
item.description: An Australian politician identified Chau Chak Wing, an Australian citizen of Chinese descent, as a co-conspirator in a 2015 bribery case.
item.dc:creator: EMILY BAUMGAERTNER and JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Killer Dogs Take 14 Lives. Did Closing Slaughterhouses Play a Role?
item.media:description: Residents of Gurpaliya village in Uttar Pradesh, India, searching for dogs that have been attacking, and killing, children with alarming frequency. Locals blame the closing of slaughterhouses, which were a source of scraps for dogs.
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.description: Villagers whose children have been killed by wild dogs blame Hindu-right politicians for closing slaughterhouses, which they say has deprived dogs of food and made them violent.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and HARI KUMAR

item.title: A Tibetan Tried to Save His Language. China Handed Him 5 Years in Prison.
item.description: Tashi Wangchuk was sentenced to five years in prison after he spoke to The New York Times about his worries that Tibetan is a dying language.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump-Kim Summit Meeting Is a ‘99.9% Done Deal,’ South Korea Says
item.media:description: A newspaper vendor this month in Singapore. President Trump and Kim Jong-un of North Korea are set to meet there next month.
item.description: South Korea moved to confront growing doubts about whether the meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un would actually take place.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Australian Archbishop Philip Wilson Guilty of Sexual Abuse Cover-Up
item.media:description: Archbishop Philip Wilson, center, arriving at a courthouse in Newcastle, Australia, on Tuesday. He was convicted of covering up abuse by a priest in the state of New South Wales in the 1970s.
item.media:credit: Peter Lorimer/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: He became the highest-ranking Catholic official to be convicted of concealing child sexual abuse, and could face two years in prison.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: How to Win an Election in Venezuela: Control the Food
item.description: Subsidized eggs and frozen chickens may help to explain why President Nicolás Maduro stayed in power. Our correspondents followed his supporters as they enticed undernourished citizens to vote for Mr. Maduro in exchange for food.

item.title: Obama, Gina Haspel, Texas: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: As Trump Adds Sanctions on Venezuela, Its Neighbors Reject Election Result
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, center, giving a victory wave in Caracas after the election results were announced on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: A group of mainly Latin American nations said the vote had not “met with the international standards of a democratic, free, just and transparent electoral process.”
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Dozens Die in Karachi From Relentless Heat
item.media:description: A volunteer sprayed water to keep people cool as temperatures reached 44 degrees Celsius (111.2 degrees Fahrenheit) in Karachi, Pakistan, on Monday.
item.description: The 15 million residents of Karachi, the Pakistani port city known as a concrete jungle, are enduring a heat wave with little relief in sight.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Italy’s Populists Move Closer to Power, With Little-Known Pick for Prime Minister
item.media:description: Giuseppe Conte in Rome, before the Italian elections this spring.
item.description: Giuseppe Conte, a civil law professor with a long résumé, must still be approved. But his main qualification may be his willingness to do the bidding of his backers.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Ken Livingstone Quits U.K. Labour Party in Anti-Semitism Dispute
item.media:description: Ken Livingstone speaking to reporters in London in April 2016. He had made remarks suggesting that Hitler had at one point supported Zionism.
item.description: The former London mayor resigned more than two years after being suspended in a dispute that was an embarrassment to the party leadership.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: U.K. Lawmakers Say Dirty Russian Money Is Still Flowing to London
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy on the exclusive avenue of Kensington Palace Gardens in March in London.
item.description: Despite the government’s tough talk, a hard-hitting parliamentary report says it is business as usual for Russian oligarchs in the city’s financial “laundromat.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: If War Comes? Stock Up on Tortillas and Wet Wipes, Sweden Suggests
item.media:description: Christina Andersson and Dan Eliasson of the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency presented the brochure “If Crisis or War Comes” in Stockholm on Monday.
item.description: The country released a revised handbook titled “If Crisis or War Comes,” its first such update since the Cold War era.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Syria Regains Control of Damascus, After Seven Years of Fighting
item.media:description: Syrian government forces on a destroyed street in the Hajar al-Aswad area on the southern outskirts of Damascus on Monday.
item.description: With the last of 1,600 militants departing from the Palestinian camp of Yarmouk, fighting around the capital is over. Peace, though, remains elusive.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: They Spoke Spanish in a Montana Store. Then a Border Agent Asked for Their IDs.
item.media:description: A Border Patrol agent stopped a pair of friends who were speaking Spanish on Wednesday inside a convenience store in Havre, Mont.
item.description: The agent told the two U.S. citizens: “It has to do with you guys speaking Spanish in the store in a state where it’s predominantly English-speaking.”
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Global Health: For First Time, W.H.O. Names Some Lab Tests ‘Essential’
item.media:description: Taking blood for an H.I.V. test at a mobile clinic in KwaZulu Natal, South Africa. The World Health Organization has recommended 113 diagnostic tests it considers essential to every health care system in the world.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Forty years after creating its “essential medicines” list, which revolutionized the struggle to get drugs to the poor, the agency tackles diagnostics.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Regional Australia, Part 2 of 2: Australia’s Immigration Solution: Small-Town Living
item.media:description: Children playing behind St. Patrick's Catholic School in Pyramid Hill, a small town in Australia being revived through immigration.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: How rural Australia opened itself to the world and became a model of integration and revival.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: In Hard-Line Speech, Pompeo Criticizes Iran’s Behavior
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo delivered a remarkably hard-line speech about Iran, offering no concessions to European leaders who want to do business with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Trump’s Charm and Threats May Not Be Working on China. Here’s Why.
item.media:description: On Monday, President Trump promoted his administration’s trade talks with China as a success, saying on Twitter that they would lead China to buy more American agricultural goods.
item.description: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: British Woman Serving 5-Year Sentence in Iran Faces New Charges
item.media:description: Richard Ratcliffe, the husband of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, held a photograph of the couple and Gabriella, their daughter, in London last month.
item.media:credit: John Stillwell/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe could have more time tacked on to her conviction for spying, possibly because of a gaffe by Boris Johnson, the British foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: ‘God Made You This Way,’ Pope Is Said to Have Told Gay Man
item.description: A Chilean survivor of sexual abuse said that during his private meeting with Pope Francis, the pontiff embraced him for who he was.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Venice Journal: A Chance to Spend 99-Plus Years in Venice (in the Afterlife)
item.media:description: The San Michele cemetery in Venice is the resting place of numerous celebrities as well as Venetians of all classes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Even if you can’t afford a palazzo on the Grand Canal, you might be able to bid for a plot in the cemetery of San Michele.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: 75-Year-Old Mayor Is Attacked in Greece, and Nationalists Rejoice
item.media:description: The mayor of Thessaloniki, Yiannis Boutaris, left, was attacked during a public gathering in the northern Greek city on Saturday.
item.description: Yiannis Boutaris, known for his outspoken views against far-right violence and racism, was assaulted at a ceremony commemorating victims of a World War I genocide.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: U.K. Unlikely to Block Comcast’s Proposed Sky Takeover, Minister Says
item.media:description: Sky holds lucrative broadcast rights for English Premier League soccer games, as well as other professional sports tournaments, and has an online streaming service.
item.description: The decision by Britain’s culture secretary is the latest twist in a takeover battle between Comcast and Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox for control of the British satellite broadcaster.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: U.K. Court Dismisses Charges Over Qatar Fund-Raising by Barclays
item.media:description: A British court has dismissed charges against Barclays over a fund-raising round during the 2008 financial crisis that gave it much-needed financial infusions without a government bailout.
item.description: The case was the first in the country against a bank for actions during the global financial crisis, and the decision is a blow to British regulators.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Death of Japanese Climber on Everest Raises Toll This Month to 3
item.media:description: The body of the Japanese climber Nobukazu Kuriki was airlifted on Monday to Kathmandu, the Nepalese capital, for an autopsy to ascertain the exact cause of his death.
item.media:credit: Ang Tashi Sherpa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Officials said Nobukazu Kuriki, who had tried to reach the summit seven other times, died after he slipped and fell near Camp Three.
item.dc:creator: RAJNEESH BHANDARI

item.title: In China, Photo of Trade Talks Embodies ‘Young’ Country Passing Aging U.S.
item.description: Social media users noticed a distinct age gap between the Chinese delegates and the American lawmakers who met them in Washington.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Grenfell Tower Inquiry Opens in London With Focus on Victims
item.media:description: The remains of Grenfell Tower in London, where a fire last year led to the deaths of 72 people.
item.description: The first nine days of the public investigation are to be devoted to tributes to the dead by friends and families, reflecting the powerful emotions at play.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
